column4: hi, does anyone know how to tell the filesystem to avoid/skip readwriting on an specific sector/block?
what filesystem?
I assume the sector is bad, have you run fsck on it?
as a short term, temporary workaround, you could just use dd to fill the sector with zero bit data (pad)
just trying to access the sector makes the disk freeze
you might also read 'man badblocks'
no use, already tried that too, the sector is broken physicaly
are you trying to save data, or work around a defective drive?
I'm trying to live, but a random day in the week a random program reads a random file thats on a broken sector, and the PC freezes until I kill that job
I know you don't like the advice given, but trust us, replacing the drive is your best option.  Everything else is just a workaround
then I'll workaround, I live in argentina, $150 is a lot of money here
thanks for your time, now I'll proceed to read the filesystem kernel code
just so you know, it's only going to get worse.
usually the coating on the drive gets damaged, and then it gets spread by the heads.
it's not like a old hardisk that fail naturally
again, the best thing I can give you is to mark them as badblocks, or pad the sector with zeros.  Even if it takes forever
this drives come failing, and seagate denies it and erases threads that discuss this, so it's their fault, but it's still usable, I just have like 5-7 broken sectors
how would I mark them as badblocks without using "badblock" ?
I believe you, sometimes you just have to keep fighting with these companies to get it fixed.
man badblocks, it talks about not using write (-w) but I think you may want to in this case
yeah I said without using badblocks cause its slow as hell and its a 1TB hardisk
thanks, bye
